DOC.HEAD: Heavy Rains Kill 32 in Northern Brazil, Thousands Homeless
DOC.TEXT: Two weeks of pounding rains in northern Brazil have killed 32 people and left thousands homeless, civil defense officials said Thursday. Worst hit was the state of Bahia, where 24 people died and 25,000 were left homeless, according to the Rio daily newspaper Jornal do Brasil. Gloria Pires da Silva, a civil defense official in the city of Santa Barbara, said 18 people died after six cars fell into a 30-foot hole that opened up after a road crumbled. Five others drowned when rivers flooded, and a man in the town of Feira de Santana died of a heart attack when he woke up and discovered several feet of water in his home, Jornal do Brasil reported. In the neighboring state of Minas Gerais, eight people died and 15,000 people were homeless, said state official Capt. Geraldo Teixeira. Seven of the eight drowned in the colonial city of Ouro Preto when waters swept a shantytown. Heavy rains fell throughout northern Brazil and hundreds have been left homeless in the rural states of Piaui, Maranhao, Goias and Tocantins.
